Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The chemistry of lignin's photochemical transformation in the environment: implications for global carbon cycling
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Environmental Chemical Sciences program of the Chemistry Division, Drs. Patrick Hatcher of Old Dominion University, Satish Myneni of Princeton University, and Christopher Hadad of The Ohio State University employ a multidisciplinary approach to study lignin, a complex organic polymer deposited in the cell walls of many plants, making them rigid and woody. Lignin is an Earth abundant organic biopolymer that provides the starting point to recycle carbon from plants into the environment. In this project, the researchers explore pathways for the molecular rearrangement of lignin to form the molecules present in soil, water and sediments. A postdoctoral associate, graduate students, and several undergraduates are trained to combine geochemistry, fundamental molecular studies, advanced analytical techniques, and modern computational modeling of complex reaction pathways. This training provides these future scientists with an interdisciplinary experience. Undergraduate and high school engagement, including diversified recruitment, is included.

In this research project, lignin is subjected to oxidative degradation by reactive oxygen species (ROS) to partially reorganize and polymerize to form humic substances. These humic substances may effectively sequester lignin-derived carbon in contrast to the theory that lignin is completely oxidized to carbon dioxide and contribute to greenhouse warming. This research subjects both synthesized and natural lignin to oxidative decomposition by ROS in the presence of aqueous iron species, mimicking environmental oxidation. The study employs Fourier transform ion cyclotron resonance mass spectrometry, multidimensional liquids and solids NMR, and synchrotron-based X-ray absorption spectroscopy to discern molecular transformation pathways. The research also provides new information regarding both the pathways and magnitude with which photochemistry and ROS affect the cycling of terrestrial carbon among Earth's large reservoirs of carbon, impacting the chemistry of terrestrial systems and oceans.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit: Lignin is the second most abundant organic macromolecule in the land plant biosphere, next to cellulose. Research to date suggests that, when plants die and are degraded in the environment, the lignin is mineralized to carbon dioxide which adds to the global pool of atmospheric carbon. The research conducted in this project shows that degradation involving both microbial degradation and abiotic degradation via reactive oxygen species and catalysis by Fe leads to the production of biologically recalcitrant organic compounds in significant abundance, contrary to expectations of complete mineralization. These recalcitrant compounds are known as condensed aromatic compounds (black carbon) and alicyclic aliphatic molecules collectively known as CRAM (carboxyl-rich alicyclic molecules). The use of Fourier transform ion cyclotron resonance mass spectrometry and multidimensional NMR were instrumental in delineating the nature of lignin transformation products and the pathways responsible for such transformations. From our studies, we suggest that the process involves depolymerization of lignin followed by hydroxylation of aromatic rings, ring-opening, electrocyclic ring closure/condensation, and competitive radical H abstraction to produce both condensed aromatic and alicyclic structures. The studies focused on the transformation of naturally-produced lignin and synthetic lignin by radicals derived from various processes (microbial enzymes, photochemistry, Fenton chemistry, superoxide radicals, singlet oxygen, and ozonation). In addition, we show that this process of lignin modification is an important one for the formation of humic materials in soils and natural waters. The organic matter thus formed can be transported to oceanic systems and either buried in sediments of the deep ocean or stored as dissolved organic matter in oceanic waters. We believe that the aromatic and alicyclic substances formed are not easily consumed by microbes and persist in the environment such that they become an important sink for organic carbon in the global carbon cycle. Accordingly, such substances are distributed widely in soils, sediments, and natural waters.

Broader impacts: The implications of this study are wide-ranging in suggesting that lignin becomes transformed to an organic cluster of molecules that have defied connectivity with lignin because the molecular motifs have been so drastically altered. Accordingly, the impact of lignin on global carbon redistribution and stabilization in the environment has potentially been grossly under-estimated by climate change modelers, geochemists, paleoclimatologists who assume that lignin is mineralized to carbon dioxide. The project has trained and supported numerous minority undergraduate students seeking advancement to STEM careers, three graduate students advancing to postdoctoral positions with the desire to become educators and scientists in the field of chemistry and engineering, and a research scientist matriculating to a faculty position at a major University.  All along the way, these individuals were trained to utilize advanced analytical equipment such as electrospray ionization coupled to Fourier transform ion cyclotron resonance mass spectrometry, multidimensional NMR, multidimensional gas chromatography/ mass spectrometry, and excitation/emission spectroscopy in a hands-on approach.
